ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Class consisted of synchronous virtual seminar meetings, and we occasionally had asynchronous Zoom meetings with classmates for homework

reading relevant short stories
reading "On Writing Well"
workshopping classmates' essays
rough or final draft of essay due each week
We used live virtual lecture with class materials on Canvas.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Essay writing, reading for craft, articulating essay ideas

I thought the readings each week (particularly Zinsser's On Writing Well) were very helpful in improving my writing technique. I learned a lot about how to write in a more concise and impactful way. I found the 5 units to be a great way of breaking up different styles of writing and they encouraged me to write about topics I wouldn't necessarily naturally be drawn to. The class discussions allowed me to listen to my classmates' thoughts and receive insight into ideas I hadn't thought of when reading the stories myself the first time. Professor Saraceni's feedback on each essay was especially helpful in making me a better writer, as she thoughtfully comments on specific parts of the document and provides general notes on the essay as a whole.

This course greatly developed my reading and writing skills. The discussions I had with my peers were insightful and the feedback I received from them and my professor contributed to my improvement in the class.

I learned so much about writing creative essays in this class. With each essay, a different weakness in my writing was exposed, and I was made a better writer because of it. This class has also inspired me to start writing on my own, something I have never wanted to do before.
How to successfully compose an interesting personal essay that is relevant to society.

I developed an understanding of effective structure and devices in non-fiction essays and developed my writing skills through drafting and revisions. I also developed these skills by closely reading essays by published authors and by my classmates.
I developed strong personal writing skills, and read / discussed in detail a collection of wonderful essays
elements of a good essay/lead/authorial perspective in a variety of different types of writing (humor, personal, place, person, cultural criticism, etc)
I refined my essay writing skills as well as my ability to read and interpret the works of others.  I learned how to take constructive criticism from my professor and my peers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was very engaging. Although there was no pressure to participate, our class always had a steady conversation and everyone was able to contribute equally. Although some of the readings were not something I would necessarily pick up in my free time, they all turned out to be quite interesting and unique. The only weakness of this course was that sometimes the the essay deadlines were tight. Sometimes, we only had a few days between when we received feedback on our first draft and when the second draft was due.

This class was overall amazing. Professor Saraceni was so great at creating a positive discussion environment and she made the entire class better. I think the only way the class could be improved is if some of the essays were taken off the syllabus, but Prof Saraceni already addressed that in our last class meeting.
This course was extremely interesting and maintained a comfortable environment for everyone.

A strength of this course is the multitude of opportunities for peer and instructor feedback. This is a key element of quickly sharpening writing skills. No weakness come to mind; this course is structured very well.

This class is engaging and well organized. The topics we cover and the essays we discussed flow very well, and the class discussions were always smooth and insightful (even over Zoom). The "Workshops" were helpful and one of the best parts of the class. Professor Saraceni gave extensive comments on each of our drafts which allowed for revision and improvement.

the discussions were always really interesting to introduce new perspectives
lots of the readings were really enjoyable
some readings weren't as relatable (featured older cultural icons) and some days had readings longer than others (could've been more consistency)

Strengths: engaging professor, well-structured syllabus, interesting course material
Weaknesses: class length is too long for Zoom format, some course material is out of date

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I did not feel that Zoom inhibited my learning experience in any significant way. Class discussions never felt awkward or dry, and Professor Saraceni did a great job of keeping the conversation flowing at all times. The five-minute breakout rooms with classmates were a nice change from the normal routine. It definitely helped me feel like I could bond with my classmates on a more personal level, like I might have been able to do in a real classroom. Also, communication through email and Canvas was effective and not too hard to keep track of.
This course was very interactive with the students, even with the pandemic.

Some flexibility with deadlines due to traveling and possible exposure was very helpful. I found the discussions and workshops very valuable, despite the online format, although it was difficult at time to access the class materials.

I think this course worked quite well as a synchronous live seminar. I appreciated how Professor Saraceni encouraged everyone to keep their cameras on and their mics unmuted, as it helped mimic an "in person" environment.

the online workshops before the final draft of each essay was really interesting - everyone was so talented, and it was so fun to read all of their work
zoom worked fine and class was usually engaging, but at times, it's definitely easy to get distracted in long online discussions
This course was completely taught on Zoom, which worked well except for the length of the class.  I feel that it is difficult to keep a class engaged for over an hour on Zoom.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Although I don't feel that my writing skills improved dramatically, I had so much fun reading and discussing all of the texts in this course as well as writing my own short stories. Professor Saraceni is super nice and she facilitates discussions so wonderfully, even over Zoom. Her feedback combined with workshopping comments were extremely helpful. The grading is not too harsh and the workload is very manageable. Would definitely recommend this class to anyone looking to read and write personal narratives and have a lot of creative freedom. It is especially great for first-years looking for their first English course at Yale. One of my favorite classes this semester!
Yes! Especially with Professor Saraceni. Students should definitely take this course because it is such a great introduction into college writing.
I would absolutely recommend this course, the workload is perfect and the writing is interesting and not stressful.

I would strongly recommend this class to any student wishing to enter a writing-heavy field. I think the skills developed would transfer well to any type of writing, although the course is rather intense so it may not be a good fit for someone just looking to fulfill a writing requirement.

Yes, I would recommend this class to everyone! I think this class would be regarding and interesting to all students, regardless of year or major. I would recommend this class to anyone who enjoys reading and writing (or wants to improve at both!).
yes! I feel like I came out of it a much better writer; I learned how to revise my work in terms of the bigger picture rather than just edit for fluency and grammar.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student because the professor is amazing and the course work is interesting and challenging.  The work load is not bad at all, and this is a great essay-based class that I would suggest to STEM majors to provide some relief from the stress of constant midterms and homework.
